page.title: 04The lifeguards
page.content: Life Guards were first brought to Jersey privately in the late 50's early 60's from{South Africa}for the summer season. One of these guards, {Bill Laverack}is still a regular on the beach. Today they are all {Australian}and are employed by the {States of Jersey Tourism Department. Their headquarters are at{El Tico. The head lifeguard,{Gerry Shannos,}has been coming for over 20 years though the others change annually. Most are based at St Ouen's as this is the most dangerous beach in terms of the tidal currents and the activities that take place, though West Park, Plemont and St Brelade also have guards. Red and yellow flags are stuck in the sand at El Tico and The Braye to denote patrolled, safe bathing areas. Wind socks are flown to show when bathing is dangerous and inadvisable.
